Climate change poses a significant risk to individuals whose livelihoods depend on the health of glacier ecosystems. This work presents a machine learning-based approach to support ecological monitoring, focusing on glaciers. Our approach utilizes semi-automated mapping from satellite images and readily available remote sensing data to create a model that identifies and outlines both clean ice and debris-covered glaciers from satellite imagery. We also release data and develop a web tool that allows experts to visualize and correct model predictions, aiming to accelerate the glacier mapping process.

Glaciers are a vital source of freshwater and are crucial to the Hindu Kush Himalayan (HKH) region both ecologically and societally. However, glaciers are shrinking at an alarming rate, which will result in diminished freshwater flow, causing adverse effects for those who rely on freshwater flow from glaciers. Additionally, glacier shrinkage is a significant factor in the current sea-level rise. Effective and efficient methods are needed to map and delineate glaciers to monitor changes and plan integrated water resource management and glacial hazard and risk management.

Remote sensing offers complementary information that can be used to monitor glaciers, allowing the estimation of parameters like snow cover, glacier elevation, and ice index over large geographical and temporal scales. However, automated methods of delineating glaciers are affected by cloud cover, variable snow conditions, and the spectral similarity of supra-glacial debris with moraines and bedrock. Semi-automated mapping methodologies, which combine outputs from automated methods with manual interventions, can address these errors but are labor-intensive and time-consuming. Machine learning techniques can play a significant role in speeding up the process.

We apply machine learning techniques to automate methods for glacier mapping from satellite imagery using semantic segmentation, a deep learning approach that performs pixel-wise classification in images. We utilize satellite imagery from Landsat and glacier labels provided by the International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD), a regional intergovernmental learning and knowledge-sharing center serving the eight regional member countries of the HKH.

Using these resources, we develop an extensible pipeline, a dataset, and baseline methods that can be used for automated glacier mapping from satellite images. We present qualitative and quantitative results describing properties of our models and deploy our models as a web-based tool to demonstrate how machine learning can complement existing workflows.

Our experiments are carried out on the HKH region, which consists of over 4 million square kilometers of hills and mountains in eight countries. Glaciers have been periodically identified and classified by experts at ICIMOD, categorized as either clean ice or debris-covered subtypes. The labels we use have been generated through a semi-automated pipeline based on hyperpixel segmentation.

Historically, ICIMOD has used the eCognition software to segment Landsat imagery into image objects defined by contiguous pixels with similar intensity values. Those hyperpixels containing debris or ice glaciers are then merged and refined manually. We release our data in the LILA BC repository, including original Landsat tiles and extracted numpy patches, along with labels and masks in shapefile and numpy formats.

The task of identifying and mapping glaciers in remote sensing images fits well within the framework of semantic segmentation. We adapted the U-Net architecture for this task, and our model architecture and methodological pipeline are described in the following sections.
